Context:
Program Name: Business Administration – Finance
Code: B130
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $4,771.00 *
International Tuition: $17,455.00 **
Location: St. James Campus
Program Description: Provides students with specialized knowledge and skills to work in the financial services sector.
Upon completion of this program, students will be able to help clients take steps to achieve their life goals through an integrated approach to the management of all their financial affairs.

* Domestic tuition is for Canadian citizens or permanent residents.
** International tuition is for students requiring a study permit.

Context: The Centre for Business programs at George Brown College is part of the School of Accounting and Finance, offering diplomas, advanced diplomas, and degree programs in Accounting & Finance, HR, Management, and Marketing that have been accredited by the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP). The specific program mentioned, B130, has a graduation rate of 83% in the 2020-21 academic year with a graduate satisfaction rate of 83%. The program offers opportunities for work experience in Business Administration – Finance with Work Experience (program code B150). Graduates of this program may pursue careers as financial advisors/planners, financial services representatives, and customer service representatives. The college's finance programs focus on Financial Management, Investment Management, Retirement Planning, Tax Planning, Insurance and Risk Management, and Estate Planning to help clients manage their financial affairs effectively.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration – Finance Program B130 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Business Administration – Finance advanced diploma program offered at George Brown College prepares students for careers in financial advisory roles such as financial advisor/planner, financial services representative, investment advisor, and customer service representative. Graduates may be eligible for advanced standing in the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program at George Brown.

Related credentials or certifications that graduates may pursue in the financial services sector include:
- Qualified Associate Financial Planner (QAFP®) designation through FP Canada
- Certified Financial Planner (CFP®) designation through FP Canada
- Canadian Securities Course (CSC) obtained through the Canadian Securities Institute
- Life License Qualification Program (LLQP) obtained through Oliver’s Learning or another approved provider

To graduate from the B130 program, students need to complete a total of 39 courses: 35 mandatory courses, 1 Business Elective, and 3 General Education Electives for the Financial Services track; or 34 mandatory courses, 2 Business Electives, and 3 General Education Electives for the Financial Planning track. The mandatory courses for the first four semesters are common to all students.

For more information on eligibility for advanced standing in the Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Financial Services) program or future study options, please contact:
- Katherine Friesen: kfriesen@georgebrown.ca
- Tracey Britt: tbritt1@georgebrown.ca
- Carolyn Fallis: cfallis@georgebrown.ca

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. Students can choose their specialization option between Financial Services or Financial Planning at the end of semester 4.
2. Students may be required to take certain courses based on placement test results before progressing to other courses. For example, students may need to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation), but these courses do not count toward the 39 courses required for graduation.
3. Students must complete three General Education courses chosen from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI).
4. Students are required to make up any failed or dropped courses before they are eligible to graduate, which can be taken during the day or in the evening through Continuing Education. Students must ensure that continuing education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program.
5. Courses offered in each semester and their respective prerequisites:
   - Semester 1: BUS 1038, COMM 2000, ECON 1032, FIN 1003, CMMK 1087, MARK 1020, MATH 1191
   - Semester 2: ACCT 1001, COMM 1034, COMP 1010, FIN 1011, PSY 1129
   - Semester 3: BUS 1056. Students are also required to select one General Education Elective.

There is no explicit mention of the name of the college or program offered in the text.

Context:
The George Brown College offers a finance program with the following learning outcomes for graduates:
- Co-ordinate the processing and maintaining of financial records in compliance with relevant policies, procedures and regulations for individuals and/or organizations.
- Co-ordinate the preparation and presentation of financial information in compliance with relevant legislation and regulations for individuals and/or organizations.
- Analyze financial reports using financial mathematics and statistics for individuals and/or organizations.
- Develop and evaluate a financial plan to meet individuals’ and/or organizations’ needs and objectives.
- Develop, implement, evaluate and coordinate marketing strategies to promote financial products and services and enhance customer service.
- Develop, implement and evaluate strategies to establish and maintain professional networking and business relationships in the finance sector.
- Analyze and evaluate the impact of economic variables, legislation, ethics, technology, and the environment on individuals’ and/or organizations’ operations within a Canadian context.
- Develop, implement, and evaluate ongoing strategies for personal and professional development, highlighting ethics, values, and standards in the finance sector.
- Coordinate the planning, implementation, management, and evaluation of team projects using project management principles.

The tuition fees for the first two semesters of the program starting in Fall 2022 are:
- Domestic students: $4,771.00 *
- International students: $17,455.00 **

Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and later dates. The program covers the curriculum required to prepare for industry-credentialing exams such as Canadian Securities Course I and II (CSC I and CSC II), Qualified Associate Financial Planner (QAFP®) Exam, and Certified Financial Planner® (CFP®) Exam.

A degree requirement is being introduced to be eligible to become a CFP Professional; visit the FP Canada website for more info if you wish to pursue that certification.

* Amounts listed are the total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters.
** Amounts listed are the total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2023.

Context:
The text provides information about various programs offered at George Brown College, specifically the FP Professional program and the Life License Qualification Program (LLQP). Here are the key factual points extracted from the text:

* FP Canada website for more info on FP Professional program.
* LLQP training course required for this program.
* Provincial examination is a part of the LLQP program.
* Exam fees are additional costs and can be found on FP Canada, Canadian Securities Institute, Oliver's Learning, or another approved provider websites.
* OSAP funding is available for this program if applicants meet eligibility criteria.
* Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent required.
* Grade 12 English (C or U) and grade 11 math (C, M or U), or grade 12 (C or U) in English and math are the minimum academic requirements.
* Mature students may take Admissions Assessment for English and math or upgrade to achieve required credits.
* George Brown College transfer guide available for college and university credit exemptions.
* Proficiency in English communications is necessary for success in the program.
* International students should visit International Admissions page for country-specific requirements.
* Domestic students apply through Ontario Colleges, international students apply through George Brown College Online Application System.
